conclusion: The problem involves determining how shadows A, B, C, and D change in position and size when the light source moves to the back right.
The image shows four objects above slabs casting shadows labeled A, B, C, and D on the ground.
Shadow A is pointing downward-left, shadow B is pointing upward-left, shadow C is pointing downward-left, and shadow D is pointing downward-left.
The light source is initially positioned in front of the objects, casting shadows towards the bottom left corner.
If the light source moves to the back right, its rays will hit the objects from behind and slightly to the right.
Shadow A, currently pointing downward-left, will move toward the top-right if the light comes from the back right.
Shadow B, currently pointing upward-left, will move toward the bottom-right if the light comes from the back right.
Shadow C, currently pointing downward-left, will become less prominent because it is blocked by other objects but will still be visible.
Shadow D, currently pointing downward-left, will move toward the top-right if the light comes from the back right.
Shadow A will shift from the bottom left to the top right.
Shadow B will shift from the top left to the bottom right.
Shadow C will remain visible but likely smaller due to the new light source angle.
Shadow D will shift from the bottom left to the top right.
